title: MultiTech product updates

title: targets.py: NRF51: support S110 builds for OTA and BOOT targets
body:
Current S110 support is only available for default (SoftDevice + App)
images.
At the moment, a BOOT image built for micro:bit will contain the S130
SoftDevice and the app will be located at 0x1c000, even though we want a
S110 SoftDevice.
Since the elf build is still done with the S110 linker script, the entry
point will be offsetted by 0x2000 and it will fail to run.

This patch creates an interface class that allows all S110 targets to
override the SoftDevices list.

Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Brucker jean-philippe.brucker@arm.com

---

@screamerbg please consider this patch as a fix for BOOT and OTA builds on the micro:bit

title: Add smart host test copy plugin
body:
This PR adds a host test copy plugin that looks to see if the flashed file has been "consumed" by the mbed to make sure that the target is ready to continue with the testing process.

The exceptions to this are the LPC1768 and LPC11U24, which do not "consume" the flashed binary.

It also uses mbedls to find the correct board in case the mbed has remounted as a different drive, which happens on Unix systems when testing in parallel.

title: Fixed stack location problem for disco and nucleo boards (STM32L4)
body:
Move main ram to the 32k L4-SRAM2 which is being retained in
standby mode. The additional 96k ram comes second.
The new memory layout preserves all vectors and stack in standby mode.
Without this fix the heap and stack overlap on Nucleo/Disco mbed releases because the stack is wrongly defined.

I hope this is correct and it helps. (this supersedes #1349)
Regards helmut@helios.de

title: Fixes reporting of failure when one test passes when using --consolidate-waterfall
body: The test framework will mistakenly print a failure when it actually does passes at least once when using the waterfall option. This fixes the issue.

title: Enabling ADC for NRF51 P26 & P27. Currently these pins can be used as…
body: … Digital In/Out or XTAL input only.

title: add nrf51 p26 & p27 to analog api
body:
Issue: 

As of today nrf51 p26 & p27 can not be used as analog input as they are missing the analog api pin map definition. This might not be a problem for the DK as those pins are connected to the external XTAL anyways but on some prototyping boards like the xuntong ptr5188 these pins are the only way to use ADC.

So these two additional lines enable analog in on p26 & 27:

Lines to be added:

```
    {p26, ADC0_0, 1},
    {p27, ADC0_0, 2},
```

Current implementation:

```
static const PinMap PinMap_ADC[] = {
    {p1, ADC0_0, 4},
    {p2, ADC0_0, 8},
    {p3, ADC0_0, 16},
    {p4, ADC0_0, 32},
    {p5, ADC0_0, 64},
    {p6, ADC0_0, 128},
    {NC, NC, 0}
};
```

title: [NUCLEO/DISCO_L476] Fix stack heap overlap issue
body: Fix issue #1348

title: STM32L4 Stack and Heap overlap problem
body:
For the new STM32L4 I found out a major problem, the first 4k of the heap overlap with the stack!
More details here: https://developer.mbed.org/questions/60933/STM32L4-Stack-and-Heap-overlap-Disco/

I believe the problem is in startup_stm32l476xx.s (Disco & Nucleo)

The following line must be inserted/changed: (TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD + TOOLCHAIN_ARM_MIKRO) initial_sp EQU 0x20018000 ; Top of RAM1 96k

This would at least enable the 96k of RAM1, however there is another 32k SRAM2 at 0x10000000-0x10008000. My preference would be use the SRAM2 for the stack and HEAP, and add the SRAM1 for additional HEAP.
Regards Helmut

title: Adding checks with mbedls throughout testing process
body:
This PR fixes a number of issues with Unix systems and testing mbeds in parallel.

Sometimes mbeds do not remount at the same mount point and serial port when testing in parallel. This PR uses mbedls throughout the testing process if the `--auto` option is used. It updates the mbed mount point before the test is copied. It also updates the serial port before it is acquired for testing.

This will allow other copy plugins (one that I will submit once this is merged) to have more control over the remounting process and improve performance.

title: Changes contains only "Copyright year information" and "KR styling". Safe to merge.
Race conditions all over LPC176X
body:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/tree/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC176X

on this architecture pin functions share registers, therefore all modules which touch them must never interrupt each other. Also if peripherals are initialized in different threads they PCONP and PCLKSEL will be race conditions. Use bit banding to fix the PCONP and PCLKSEL.

title: Race condtion in LPC11CXX ADC
body:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC11XX_11CXX/analogin_api.c#L51

race condition on SYSAHBCLKCTRL  if different peripherals init on different threads.

title: Race condtion in LPC11CXX CAN
body:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC11XX_11CXX/TARGET_LPC11CXX/can_api.c#L274

race condition on SYSAHBCLKCTRL if init or free of different peripherals run on different threads. 
also on PRESETCTRL for same reason
also on PC_CAN->STAT if can_read and can_write interrupt each other (one of them running on an IRQ)

title: Race condtion in LPC11CXX serial
body:
https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC11XX_11CXX/serial_api.c#L63 
Race condition on SYSAHBCLKCTRL, if different uarts (or other peripherals for that matter) are initialized on different threads it can corrupt SYSAHBCLKCTRL.

title: Fix typo in documentation
Added ultra low power mode VLLS0 + POR disabled to Freescale KLXX devices
body:
On freescale KLXX devices we cannot reach lowest power consumption mode with `deepsleep()` api. This pull requests, adds a new api for these devices, called `ultradeepsleep()`.

This new api, set VLLS0 power mode and disables POR, ensuring the lowest power consumption mode. After that, only a hard RESET can wake the device up again.

title: Drivers for SAMD21
Fixed linker script for LPCXpresso for EA LPC11U35 QuickStart Board
body:
After version 7.5.0 the compiler used in LPCXpresso IDE changed and as a
result some of the included libraries were changed. This caused a
build error when trying to compile exported mbed projects.

The error was with NewlibNano libraries (*_s.a) and as NewlibNano is
not used by mbed, this patch references the non-NewlibNano libraries
instead.

This change in the linker script has been verified on LPCXpresso IDE versions
from 6.1.2 up to the current 7.9.0.

Other users have reported this has fixed the 'flash will load but wont run' issue.

Sync command in test suite causes --parallel option to fail
body:
```
Executing 'python host_test.py -d /media/bridan01/MBED5 -f "/home/bridan01/dev/myfork/mbed/build/test/LPC1768/GCC_ARM/MBED_26/div.bin" -p /dev/ttyACM1 -t 10 -C 1.5 -m LPC1768'
Test::Output::Start
.MBED: Instrumentation: "/dev/ttyACM1" and disk: "/media/bridan01/MBED5"
HOST: Copy image onto target...
cp: failed to access ‘/media/bridan01/MBED4/timeout.bin’: Permission denied
.Test::Output::Finish
TargetTest::K64F[0]::GCC_ARM::MBED_24::Timeout Int us [TIMEOUT] in 30.31 of 15 sec
Building project TIME_US (K64F, GCC_ARM)
Executing 'python host_test.py -d /media/bridan01/MBED4 -f "/home/bridan01/dev/myfork/mbed/build/test/K64F/GCC_ARM/MBED_25/time_us.bin" -p /dev/ttyACM0 -t 15 -C 4 -m K64F'
Test::Output::Start
cp: failed to access ‘/media/bridan01/MBED4/time_us.bin’: Permission denied
MBED: Instrumentation: "/dev/ttyACM0" and disk: "/media/bridan01/MBED4"
HOST: Copy image onto target...
Test::Output::Finish
```

Note the lines where cp fails with the error `cp: failed to access ... Permission denied`.

I've also gotten mbeds into a sort of deadlock, where every test after a certain point times out.

This also happens to a lesser degree when running multiple instances of singletest.py in different terminals without using `--parallel`.

That being said, I haven't had an issue with it when testing multiple mbeds without the `--parallel` option. But it takes quite a while to test when you have lots of boards connected.

title: KL25 - USBHID read returns invalid data if usb is disconnected during a read
body: If the usb cable is disconnected during a call to USBHID::read(), the function will return success, along with filling the buffer passed in with invalid data.  The invalid data matches that at address 0, since it is copied from a null pointer.  This appears to be caused by the end endpoints being reconfigured as an isochronous ( =0) during the usb disconnect, since isochronous reads and writes return immediately.  Also, if a write is in progress instead of a read, a hard fault will occur.

title: LPC81X: reduce code size and add ARM_GCC support
body:
LPC810 has only 4KB of flash, thus avoiding dead code is really nice.
Here the NVIC interrupt setup was pulled from the us_ticker code even
if no code is using timer events.

This also adds ARM_GCC support for TARGET_LPC81X.

LPC81X and LPC82X support Cortex M0+ VTOR register, so it is not
necessary to put non-init text at 0x200.

title: Tools: singletest.py option -c with shell copy method as default copy method
body:
# Description

This PR aligns how mbed 2 and 3 use `-c` of switch for `singletest.py`.
Note: `-c` switch allows users to select binary copy method.

With this change default copy (mbed flashing) method will be changed from `shutil` to default OS shell copy command:
- posix: `cp`, `sync`
- Windows: `copy`

This hopefully will prevent issues such as 'flashing failed due to shutil.copy() implementation defects';
mbed interface chip handles well default OS copy commands, not Python's `shutil.copy()`.

title: Remaining drivers for SAMR21
Sync and Remount Copy and Waiting Reset Plugins for Test Suite
body:
This pull request adds two copy plugins and one reset plugin to the test suite.
# Copy Plugins
- **sync:** This copy plugin attempts to use synchronous system calls to flash the test binary. 
- **remount:** This copy plugin tries to solve the issue with certain mbed boards appearing to run out of disk space on Linux and Mac. This plugin unmounts then remounts each board to refresh the disk usage data in the OS so that flashing can continue (hopefully) indefinitely.

Both of these plugins are fairly experimental, however it would help if they were merged so I can start testing them in the CI system.

**NOTE:** This moves all python "sleep" commands out of the general host_test execution and into the specific copy plugins. I have added the sleeps back into the existing plugins.
# Reset Plugin
- **wait:** Not a particularly elegant plugin, but this simple adds a 2 second delay before the mbed platform is reset. This fixes issues with boards that reset after flashing. They tend to confuse the test suite by outputting serial data immediately before the soft reset is attempted. By waiting for a short amount of time, we can be sure to flush this data before resetting the mbed.

title: LED error patterns
body:
Since Martin wanted me to post it here, and otherwise we never get the 200 open issues:

The two original mbeds have a very nice, very obvious, error pattern. But that only works for the 4 LEDs on that board, while pretty much no other board has 4 seperate LEDs. Some of the other mbeds don't even have error LEDs (although they seem to be being added now). Some of these are red, which you could say indicates an error. But enough simply have no red LEDs, and only have a green LED for example. On all boards with RGB LEDs (Freescale to start with), it is pretty much random which color it blinks, depending on the state of the other colors of the RGB LED. It can blink red, but it might very well blink purple-blue (if the blue LED is enabled), or yellow-white (if green/blue LEDs are enabled).

Now add to it that blinking an LED isn't exactly special: The original mbed pattern was special, but if a green LED is blinking I don't immediatly think: "Ah an error". I assume it is just blinking because half my programs have random LEDs blinking. 

So the main problem is a lack of consistency. Try to describe how a new user knows an error happened in one sentence, good luck. "A certain LED blinks, or multiple LED blinks, something blinks, that tells you an error happened".

Solution I see: Make a distinct blinking pattern (for example 4 times fast, 4 times slow. As long as it is something that you notice clearly as out of the ordinary). Document this somewhere where new users will actually see it (!!!), new users especially will run often into this, everytime they use wrong pins for a peripheral. And use this same error patterns for every board. Just blink all LEDs in this pattern, then you don't need different defines for each board (and then also remove the target specific disable_irq, just disable them for all). 

And if you really want you can let the two original mbeds keep their funky blinking pattern, but also in this new speed pattern, so as example 4 times fast, 4 times slow).

title: [Silicon Labs] Fix incorrect clock selection
body:
In certain cases, the clock selection in the board header did not take effect, even though HFXO was requested.

Root cause: you cannot use a C-enum name in a #if compare, because the preprocessor will replace all enum names with 0 (so all checks on HFXO/LFXO checked out regardless of the define).

title: Tools: Added verbose mode to mbed library build when using singletest.py
body:
# 　Description

This is a minor change but improves toolchain issues investigations and assigns proper behavior to verbose flag.

Added verbose mode to mbed library build when using `singletest.py` `-v` (verbose) switch
# Rationale

When using

```
$ cd mbed/workspace_tools
$ singletest.py ... -v
```

verbose prints from mbed SDK library build were not shown.
When debugging issues related to compiler flags etc. those verbose messages should be visible.
# Test and example output

```
$ singletest.py --auto -v
```

``` make
[DEBUG] Command: c:/Keil/ARM/ARMCC\bin\armcc -c --cpu=Cortex-M4.fp --gnu -Otime --split_sections --apcs=interwork --brief_diagnostics --restrict --multibyte_chars -O3 -Ic:/Keil/ARM/ARMCC\include -DTARGET_KPSDK_MCUS -DTARGET_FF_ARDUINO -D__CORTEX_M4 -DCPU_MK64FN1M0VMD12 -DTARGET_FRDM -DTARGET_CORTEX_M -D__FPU_PRESENT=1 -DMBED_BUILD_TIMESTAMP=1439369410.9 -DTARGET_KPSDK_CODE -DTARGET_M4 -D__MBED__=1 -DARM_MATH_CM4 -DTARGET_K64F -DTARGET_Freescale -DFSL_RTOS_MBED -DTOOLCHAIN_ARM -DTARGET_MCU_K64F -DTOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD -IC:\Work\przemek2\mbed\libraries\mbed\targets\cmsis -IC:\Work\przemek2\mbed\libraries\mbed\targets\cmsis\TARGET_Freescale -IC:\Work\przemek2\mbed\libraries\mbed\targets\cmsis\TARGET_Freescale\TARGET_MCU_K64F -IC:\Work\przemek2\mbed\libraries\mbed\targets\cmsis\TARGET_Freescale\TARGET_MCU_K64F\TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD -E -o C:\Work\przemek2\mbed\build\mbed\.temp\TARGET_K64F\TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD\TARGET_Freescale\TARGET_MCU_K64F\TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD\startup_MK64F12.o.E.s C:\Work\przemek2\mbed\libraries\mbed\targets\cmsis\TARGET_Freescale\TARGET_MCU_K64F\TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD\startup_MK64F12.S
```

title: ST BLoD Fix
body:
## Problem

All ST boards do not have the blue lights of death. on calling `error()` the message will print, but the led lights will not blink, this PR adds BLoD to all ST boards. 
## Solution

Add requisite lines to the device.h files to enable BLoD behavior (All ST Boards have a single led)
## Future Improvements
- improve the BLOD routine so its generic for one light (ie get change the ERROR_LED_RED to something like ERROR_LED_SINGLE) 
- change rate of blink to be random-ish like true siren lights are
- get partners to add this to all the ST Board derivitives (ublox, mdot, archmax)

title: [LPC15XX] Fix GPIO port word pin registers offset
body:
Adjust offset for GPIO port word pin registers from 0x100 to 0x1000.

The updated SVD file supporting this change can be found on the [lpcware](https://www.lpcware.com/content/nxpfile/lpc1500-svd-file) site.

I don't think any existing code makes use of the GPIO word pin registers, but I've manually verified that they work on an LPCXpresso 1549 board.

title: [RZ_A1H]Add RZ_A1H in RPC. Modify communication problem of Ethernet.
body:
Hi,

We added RZ_A1H in RPC.
And we modified a problem that sometimes fail to "pbuf_alloc" function in Ethernet.

Regards,
Yamanaka

title: USB device - Current consumption stays high before 1st connect
body:
We've been working on the USB Device for a while and we noticed that there is some shortcomings in the USB device library which result in the high current consumption before (any class) USB device is connected for the 1st time. There has been already reported couple of issues “USB Serial constructor blocking" (https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/53) and “Allow USBDevice::connect() to be non-blocking" (https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/issues/169) with some level of fixes.
Related to the issues mentioned there is also another potential way to correct the issues. Constructing the Serial (or MSD class) object a bit differently, current consumption can be limited in the main function: `USBSerial (VID, PID, REL, false)`. This is possible with Serial and MSD classes as they support non-blocking construction.
**However this still leaves Audio and HID classes with the current consumption issue as they do not support non-blocking construction**.

title: [MAXWSNENV, MAX32600MBED] Simplifying pwm search. Reordering PinMap_PWM.
[Tools] Bugfix duplicate macros
body:
# Description

While compiling for IAR for platforms:
- NRF51822::IAR
- NRF51_DONGLE::IAR
- HRM1017::IAR
- ARCH_BLE::IAR
- SEEED_TINY_BLE::IAR

we've got duplicated macros definitions in IAR compiler command line calls.
# Fix & Test

Compiler was fed with few identical -D macro definitions. In toolchains, function returning symbols should return unique set of values.

After patch compilation for IAR passes fine:

```
$ build.py -t IAR -m NRF51822,NRF51_DONGLE,HRM1017,ARCH_BLE,SEEED_TINY_BLE -j 8
```

```
Building library CMSIS (NRF51822, IAR)
Building library MBED (NRF51822, IAR)
Building library CMSIS (NRF51_DONGLE, IAR)
Building library MBED (NRF51_DONGLE, IAR)
Building library CMSIS (HRM1017, IAR)
Building library MBED (HRM1017, IAR)
Building library CMSIS (ARCH_BLE, IAR)
Building library MBED (ARCH_BLE, IAR)
Building library CMSIS (SEEED_TINY_BLE, IAR)
Building library MBED (SEEED_TINY_BLE, IAR)

Completed in: (1.01)s

Build successes:
  * IAR::NRF51822
  * IAR::NRF51_DONGLE
  * IAR::HRM1017
  * IAR::ARCH_BLE
  * IAR::SEEED_TINY_BLE
```
## Impact on other toolchains

```
$ build.py -t GCC_ARM,ARM -m NRF51822,NRF51_DONGLE,HRM1017,ARCH_BLE,SEEED_TINY_BLE -j 8

Building library MBED (HRM1017, GCC_ARM)
Building library CMSIS (ARCH_BLE, GCC_ARM)
Building library MBED (ARCH_BLE, GCC_ARM)
Building library CMSIS (SEEED_TINY_BLE, GCC_ARM)
Building library MBED (SEEED_TINY_BLE, GCC_ARM)
Building library CMSIS (NRF51822, ARM)
Building library MBED (NRF51822, ARM)
Building library CMSIS (NRF51_DONGLE, ARM)
Building library MBED (NRF51_DONGLE, ARM)
Building library CMSIS (HRM1017, ARM)
Building library MBED (HRM1017, ARM)
Building library CMSIS (ARCH_BLE, ARM)
Building library MBED (ARCH_BLE, ARM)
Building library CMSIS (SEEED_TINY_BLE, ARM)
Building library MBED (SEEED_TINY_BLE, ARM)

Completed in: (1.45)s

Build successes:
  * GCC_ARM::NRF51822
  * GCC_ARM::NRF51_DONGLE
  * GCC_ARM::HRM1017
  * GCC_ARM::ARCH_BLE
  * GCC_ARM::SEEED_TINY_BLE
  * ARM::NRF51822
  * ARM::NRF51_DONGLE
  * ARM::HRM1017
  * ARM::ARCH_BLE
  * ARM::SEEED_TINY_BLE
```

title: Nordic: handle unwanted RTC interrupts
body:
This patch clears the EVENT_COMPARE register even when we're not
expecting to get a COMPARE interrupt.

Here is a scenario where we get an unwelcome interrupt, and where it
currently results in a deadlock:
- A Ticker T1 runs at 500ms
- Its handler registers a Timeout T2 at 20µs. Since LF clock runs at
  32.768kHz, this will be rounded up to a multiple of 30.5µs (actually
  61µs, to ensure we're in the next tick window)

```
           T1  T2                                T1' T2'
    -------|---|---------------------------------|---|--------->
           :   :                                 :
           <---> n * 30.5µs                      :
           <--------------- 500ms --------------->
```
- When the ticker API handles T1, it calls us_ticker_set_interrupt a
  first time for T1', and then for registering T2.
- Since T2 period is less than one RTC tick (30.5µs), there is a high
  chance it will go past _while_ we're still in this first handler.
- So ticker_irq_handler also handles T2 as well, and removes it from the
  queue.
- us_ticker_set_interrupt is called for T1' before returning from
  ticker_irq_handler

The problem resides in the fact that us_ticker_set_interrupt takes more
than 2 RTC ticks to execute: while inside the handler, T2 interrupt will
fire.
- Because of this pending interrupt, RTC1_IRQHandler will be called
  right away, but since we removed T2 from the queue, the handler is
  waiting for T1' instead, and will not clear EVENT_COMPARE until we
  reach the T1' tick, in about 500ms.
- This results in a lock and main isn't executed anymore.

With this patch, we avoid being stuck in RTC1_IRQHandler while waiting
for T1'.

Note: even when T2 isn't handled in the same loop as T1, we may get a
spurious interrupt, because us_ticker_set_interrupt will be called twice
for T2... and will register T2+m the second time, while T2 interrupt is
fired in the background.
That case isn't as harmful, since RTC1_IRQHandler will be waiting for
T2+m, which is only one or two ticks further, and then it won't be
called again before T1'.

Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Brucker jean-philippe.brucker@arm.com

title: Added requirements.txt file
body: 'pip install -r requirements.txt' will install all the needed python packages

title: [nRF51] System off & Pin 31 disabled
body:
I found two commented lines when using mbed for the nRF51822 without any apparent reason which cause some troubles.
- [The first one](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_MCU_NRF51822/TARGET_NRF51822_MKIT/PinNames.h#L64) should enable system off mode [(Nordic ref. on this topic)](https://github.com/NordicSemiconductor/nrf51-powerdown-examples).
- [The last one](https://github.com/mbedmicro/mbed/blob/master/libraries/mbed/targets/hal/TARGET_NORDIC/TARGET_MCU_NRF51822/sleep.c#L31) disables the usage of pin number 31.

I'd like to know why are they commented out before I submit a pull request.

title: Change DELTA_DFCM_NNN40 ram size to 32KB config
body: Change DELTA_DFCM_NNN40 ram size to 32KB config

title: Changed NZ32-SC151 external oscillator to 16MHz, and moved defines to device.h
body: For NZ32-SC151 fixed External oscillator frequency to 16MHz, and moved defines to device.h

title: Nordic: fallback to the internal LF clock in case Xtal doesn't start
body:
Since some Nordic platforms don't use an external clock source, they
need to be built with the TARGET_NRF_LFCLK_RC flag. If they don't,
SystemInit will wait indefinitely for an external clock to start.

This patch adds a 1s timeout to the external oscillator initialisation,
and falls back to using the internal RC one if no LFCLKSTARTED event was
received in this interval.

For most applications, this won't matter. When building for the wrong
Nordic target, pin numbers will be mixed up as well and the application
will break later on.
But on targets that can only be updated using FOTA and don't have an
interface chip, this patch avoid ending up with a bricked device after a
slight mistake. Indeed, BLE DFU service is portable across all boards
and will run even with a mixed-up target setup, allowing the user to
re-install the right application.

An example scenario is transferring an application on a standalone
NRF51 chip, after spending some time prototyping on an mKIT, which tends
to happen a bit too often...

Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Brucker jean-philippe.brucker@arm.com
